utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""UNDER THE WIRE"")
She was completely full up with the horror of the situation and what she had seen.
And I said, Marie, what is your exit strategy?
And there was a pause.
And she said, that's just it.
There isn't one.
And that was when I really, really began to worry.
Yeah.
We did discuss reporting from the outside.
But I think the further back you get from the actual center of what's happening, I - you know, I think the reports become more diluted.
You know, it wasn't at that point that it was a suicide mission.
But we also knew that if we mentioned this to the editors, they would just say no. So we rather discreetly turned our phones off.
Conroy barely made it out of Syria alive.
Opposition activists helped him escape, first on a truck, then the back of a motorbike and, at one point, crawling through a sewer drain.
When we talked from his home in the English countryside, Conroy said he intends to honor the promise he made to the people he left behind in Syria to keep telling their story.
As for him, he's endured multiple surgeries.
He's now 54.
I mean, how does this career one day come to a close for you?
Is it by design or by accident?
You know, to be honest, I go through this a lot.
You know, I think I said once, I'll rest on this story when them Syrians are safely home in bed.
I never thought it would be seven years later.
I don't think any of us who are - been involved in it would think that, seven years later, we'd still be doing this.
I don't think I have full control over how this ends.
And until that situation resolves, then I have to keep doing this out of, you know, that promise I made.
Paul Conroy, war photographer.
He's author of the book ""Under The Wire,"" about his and Marie Colvin's last assignment together in Syria.
It's now been made into a documentary, which comes out tomorrow.
Paul Conroy, thank you.
Been a pleasure.
Thanks for having us.
Cheers.
(SOUNDBITE OF PODINGTON BEAR'S ""SOLEMN OATH"")
And speaking of drama on the football field, high school games are taking to the national stage.
Networks such as Fox Sports Net, MTV and NBC all now broadcast high school games.
Tonight, ESPNU will feature a game between two Washington teams: the Coolidge Colts and Dunbar High's Crimson Tide.
NPR's Doualy Xaykaothao visited each team to see how they were handling the pre-game pressure.
(Soundbite of announcement)
(ESPN) The bright lights are shining and it's time for a high school football showdown.
Doug Bell is ESPNU's play-by-play man for special coverage of high school football games this season.
He'll call the game between rivals Calvin Coolidge and Dunbar.
Unidentified Man #2: Ready, set, hut.
Good move.
Fight them.
Fight them.
Come back.
Out on the fields of both high schools, the players and their coaches get ready for the big game.
The Coolidge Colts sport their silver and orange uniforms during a drill on this gorgeous fall afternoon.
(Soundbite of helicopter)
Unidentified Man #1: (Unintelligible) Break down.
Good.
Over at Dunbar, the players dress in red and black, a helicopter flies over ahead while an assistant coach helps players with their footwork.
Sitting in the bleachers, head football coach Craig Jeffries says the nationally televised game means a lot to his kids.
These kids, inner-city kids, that normally, you know, dream about playing on TV and going to the pro NFL, playing in the pros, and this will probably be as close as they can get to it.
Coach Jeffries has led his team to seven city championships in 8 years.
He says the national exposure gives his players a chance to shine.
They have an opportunity to be famous.
You know, you're talking about your 15 minutes of fame and everybody is entitled to it.
Well, there's some kids on our team with special needs, there's some kids on our team that know it that they're not going to play or start.
But, you know, we talk about the whole team concept and, you know, it's not going to be one individual on TV, it's going to be a team.
Jason Lane, head football coach at Coolidge, agrees.
He says the exposure is good but it will add pressure to his players.
But, you know, what I've talked to them about is let's just go out and play it like every game.
And just do the best you can.
Regardless of the outcome, do the best you can.
We're going to be proud of you, and we'll go from there.
Unidentified Man #2: Let me go.
Unidentified Man #3: Go.
Unidentified Man #4: Let me see your hands up.
Way to get your hands up.
Unidentified Man #3: Yeah.
Go.
Unidentified Man #4: Yeah.
Unidentified Man #3: Hey.
Unidentified Man #4: You can't get held up by that man.
Pausing from a scrimmage, 16-yeard-old Terrence Yarber(ph) of Coolidge says he's fired up about being on television.
Everybody is out here to show what they got for the scouts or whatever.
So what better place to do it than on TV?
Unidentified Man #5: Good, don't cross your feet.
Break it down.
Good.
Move it back.
Back at Dunbar, quarterback Nathan Bussey says he's not nervous at all about being on television.
We call them butterflies.
But, you know, I've never had them before any game because I've been playing this sport for a long time.
And the butterflies, they just - they never appear.
This 17-year-old has been playing football since he was five.
Teammate Kris Williams plays middle linebacker for Dunbar.
He says the televised game is a chance to be seen by college recruits and new fans.
It exposes us to colleges, too.
So they can see us play on a national level and to fans that love high school football, high school sports, period.
Daniel Martinez Freguso is a 70-year-old farmer whose son was kidnapped three years ago.
Unlike the Marti family, which hired a private security firm to negotiate with the kidnappers and investigate their case, Martinez says he has no money.
And he went to the public authorities.
(Spanish spoken)
They've done nothing, he says.
He has taken the case to local, state, and federal officials, and he says none of them have done anything.
Worst yet, Martinez, like many Mexicans, believes the local authorities are under the control of organized criminals and will never pursue his son's abduction.
Sitting in a wheelchair with a white cowboy hat jutting from his head, Martinez says he wants the federal government to impose the death penalty for kidnapping.
(Spanish spoken)
Apply the death penalty, Mr. President, he says.
If you wear trousers, apply the death penalty.
It's not fair that our family is suffering this way.
He says he has lost the ability to walk since his son was taken.
Do something, he cries.
President Felipe Calderon has tried to do something.
Since he took office 20 months ago, Calderon has launched an all-out war against the nation's drug smuggling cartels.
Other syndicates run kidnapping and extortion rackets.
Calderon has sent tens of thousands of soldiers and federal police to fight the gangs.
This week, the Mexican president presented his state of the union address, and much of it focused on crime.
(Spanish spoken)
Since my first day as president, Calderon said, security has been the highest priority of my government.
There is no other issue to which we dedicated as much attention and resources to resolve.
The federal government is attempting to clean up and professionalize the Mexican police.
To root out crooked cops, the government has started issuing lie detector and drug tests to all federal police officers.
(Spanish spoken)
Nothing offends people more than corruption, the president declared.
And particularly when the corruption is in the police.
Calderon noted that his war on crime has also taken a toll on honest, dedicated cops.
More than 100 officers have been killed since he took power, including the chief of the federal police.
Calderon said the country is in the midst of a difficult battle against powerful criminal forces, but he said it's a battle Mexico is going to win.
Jason Beaubien, NPR News, Mexico City.
Today is an especially poignant day for Iraqi Kurd Qubad Talabani.
He is the son of the president of Iraq.
The month of March is bittersweet for many Iraqi Kurds.

Not only does this month mark the fifth anniversary of the liberation of all Iraqis from Saddam's reign of terror, but it is also the anniversary of the genocide against the Kurdish residents of Halabja.
A variety of poison gases were used to exterminate innocent men, women and children 20 years ago this very day on March 16.
The genocide of the Kurds between 1987 and 1988 included the brutal attack on Halabja as part of the Anfal operation - a larger campaign intended to annihilate the Kurds of Iraq.
